title: Spring Rains

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on canvas.

description: In Spring Rains, Victor Higgins featured two Native Americans on horseback amidst a sublime landscape. He depicted El Salto Peak ringed with clouds and flooded the valley below with light, creating shimmering atmospheric effects with his vibrant palette. As the artist once observed, “A field or a mountain is always changing. They change size and color with every passing cloud and with the passing of every hour and season.” Higgins studied and taught at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. He first went to Taos, New Mexico, in 1914, sponsored by a group of Chicagoans who wanted to support local artists. Liberated from financial concerns, Higgins experimented boldly with modern form and color.
publication_history: Judith A. Barter, Window on the West: Chicago and the Art of the New Frontier, 1890–1940, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago; New York and Manchester, VT: Hudson Hills Press, 2003), ii, 67, 68, 133, cat. 49, fig. 31 (ill.).
exhibition_history: Indiana, South Bend Art Association, American Painting in the Manner of the Late Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries, Feb. 10–Mar. 31, 1948. Chicago, University Club, long term loan, 1954–1981. Phoenix Art Museum, Victor Higgins: an American Master, Dec. 14, 1990–Feb. 10, 1991; Cody, Wyoming, Buffalo Bill Center, Mar. 1–May 17, 1991; South Bend, Indiana, University of Notre Dame, Snite Museum of Art, June 6–Sept. 22, 1991; Tulsa, Gilcrease Museum, Oct. 20–Dec. 29, 1991; Los Angeles, Autry Museum, Jan. 26–Mar. 14, 1992; Indianapolis, Eiteljorg Museum of American Indians and Western Art, Apr. 7–May 31, 1992. Tulsa, Gilcrease Museum, Taos Artists and Their Patrons, May 16–July 18, 1999; South Bend, Indiana, University of Notre Dame, Snite Museum of Art, Aug. 15–Nov. 14, 1999; Phoenix Art Museum, Dec. 11, 1999–Mar. 12, 2000; Albuquerque Museum, Apr. 16–July 16, 2000; San Antonio, McNay Art Museum, Aug. 13–Nov. 12, 2000 (Phoenix, Albuquerque, and San Antonio only). Art Institute of Chicago, Window on the West: Chicago and the Art of the New Frontier, 1890–1940, June 28–Oct. 13, 2003, cat. 49.
provenance_text: Walter Victor Higgins (1884–1949), by Dec. 1923; partially exchanged for The Pumpkin Girl (formerly acquired by the Art Institute of Chicago, Friends of American Art, 1920) and sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1924.
